required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sleep Duration in Women With Previous Gestational Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Sleep Extension on Glucose Metabolism in Women With Previous Diagnosis of Gestational Diabetes

brief_summary.textblock: Women with a history of gestational diabetes (GDM) are at high risk of developing diabetes in the future. Sleep disturbances are emerging as risk factors for incident diabetes. The purpose of this study is to test the effects of 6-week sleep extension in women with a history of GDM and short sleep on glucose metabolism by randomized controlled study.

detailed_description.textblock: The primary aim of this study is to evaluate the effects of a sleep extension intervention in non-diabetic women with a prior history of GDM and habitual short sleep duration on the outcomes of glucose metabolism. The participants will be randomized to a 6-week sleep extension intervention group, using technology-assisted sleep intervention, or a healthy living information control group. Glucose metabolism parameters will be assessed by an oral glucose tolerant test.

primary_outcome.description: Changes in serum glucose and insulin levels from oral glucose tolerant test (at 0,30,60,90 and 120 minutes) between baseline and 6 weeks
Changes in sleep duration from baseline to 6 weeks

secondary_outcome.description: Pittsburgh sleep quality index (range 0 to 21 with higher score reflecting worse sleep quality)
Changes in weight, caloric intake, appetite, energy metabolism from baseline to 6 weeks
Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (range 0-60 with higher score reflecting more depressive symptoms)

intervention.description: Sleep extension aims to increase sleep duration for at least 30 minutes using weekly coaching
Participants will receive weekly health education

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Premenopausal women, age 18-45, with a history of GDM who currently do not have diabetes
- At least one year post-partum
- Reported habitual sleep duration <7h/night during work- or weekdays with a desire to sleep longer
- Reported time spent in bed =<8 hours
- Own a smartphone compatible with Fitbit.
- No need to provide care at night for her child(ren), defined as >3 times a week and >30 minutes at a time
- No history of obstructive sleep apnea, insomnia, or restless leg syndrome
Exclusion Criteria:
- A1C ≥6.5%
- Currently pregnant or planning pregnancy or breast feeding
- Insomnia symptoms defined as severe as assessed by the Insomnia Severity Index (score ≥15)
- Rotating shift or night shift work
- High risk for obstructive sleep apnea screened by STOP BANG questionnaire.
- Significant medical morbidities, such as congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease requiring oxygen, active treatment for cancer or psychiatric problem, history of stroke with neurological deficits, cognitive impairment, kidney failure requiring dialysis, illicit drug use.

eligibility.gender_description: Non-diabetic women with a previous history of gestational diabetes

reference.citation: Bellamy L, Casas JP, Hingorani AD, Williams D. Type 2 diabetes mellitus after gestational diabetes: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Lancet. 2009 May 23;373(9677):1773-9. doi: 10.1016/S0140-6736(09)60731-5.

Postpartum resolution of obstructive sleep apnea in women with gestational diabetes and the relationship with glucose metabolism.
